title: Ranking Web Sites with Real User Traffic
segmentation: Hello so I'll be presenting on ranking websites with real user traffic which is actually sort of 1 facet of the research I'm going to be presenting.
What this is all based on was you'll be seeing is a very large collection of actual user traffic information that we've been mining various aspects of.
For about a year now.
So it's a broad outline.
I'm going to explain to you what exactly the data set is that I'm talking about here.
Some of the interesting structural properties when able to recover from it.

Some of the behavioral patterns we observe, and then some work in validating some of the basic assumptions made by the Pagerank algorithm and the random Surfer model, and then some patterns we observe in the temporal aspect.
The data.
So there have been a lot of different sources for ranking data.

The one that's been studied the most, of course is the link graph, which is of course the basis of the random Surfer model, where we're just taking a static look at the web at which web pages have connections to which other web pages.
Well, there are of course many other sources for ranking data, a lot of which are more dynamic.

For example, we can do studies based on network flow data, where we're getting information about the different conversations that are going on between different nodes in the network can get information from there.
There are studies that have taken a look at web server logs where we have a look at which pages on the site have been hit most often and so forth.
This has been done at, say, the level of an entire universities, official web server space, so.
You can get some very large datasets, but you're also then worried about bias because only thing you're looking at is a particular kind of webpage and officially hosted ones and so forth.
And then of course there are various toolbars and plugins which are able to log the data.
Alexis very famous in this regard or the Google toolbar which are generating click streams as the user is used.
These toolbars you have information about which links they clicked on at what time.

We are choosing to go much more directly to the heart of the matter and actually take a look at the wire itself, so our source of data is the Indiana University data Network, which has about 100,000 users or so at 8 branch campuses.
This a branch campuses all connect to the outside Internet through a pipe that's constantly full with about 600 to 800 megabytes.
A second of traffic that's aggregated everything to both the commercial and academic Internet together.
So the way we actually get usable web data out of there.
Is we've got a data collector that has a mirror of all the traffic between you and the outside world.
Now we aren't able to actually inspect every packet in real time because there's simply too much.
But when we're running at peak traffic levels, we can look at about 30% of all the traffic.
So what we do is we take a look just at the packets that are destined to HTTP or port 80.
We then immediately anonymized the data, so we're not retaining any information about individual client identity.
So in order to preserve user privacy, IP addresses and so forth are completely dropped.
We take a look at inside this packet headed to port 80 and make see whether it's got an HTTP get request in it.
If it does have a get request, we record a number of fields that we're able to get from that packet.
Which are we?
First we find out what virtual host is being requested.
This is important because we can't determine what web servers being contacted simply from a destination IP address.
1 server may host many sites, so we need to get the virtual host.
We get what path is being requested.
We also take a look at what the referring site is in a lot of cases.
Of course going to be empty, as when somebody.
Just opens up a bookmark, but in a lot of cases we have evidence that link is being followed from one site to another.

We also take a look at the user agent simply to find out heuristically whether or not this link was likely to be generated by a user, or whether it's a crawler bot or some other form of web experiment going on, and then we can do some filtering to make sure that it's sites from our users looking out and not the outside world looking in.

We divide this into two datasets were keeping this information both for every single web request that we can possibly find, and then just a human data set, which is a refinement of that where we are stripping out everything that is unlikely to be a request for an actual web page that somebody would look at.
So we're stripping out all the images and stylesheets and everything which everyone human web request actually generates about 14 other requests for style sheets and all these other items.
So for the remainder of this talk, will actually be focusing in on this human data set, which is based on about nine months worth of data for what I'm showing here, including down here about.
We've got about 1 billion requests in the data set right now, representing about four million different web servers are being contacted with about 11 million edges among all those servers.
Now we're collecting this data here at the server level, so our individual nodes in the graph.
Our web servers, as identified by virtual hosts and HTTP requests.
And the diagram you see here is actually what you get when you take a look at some of the most navigated highways of the data.
I invite you to take a look in the paper for discussion of how exactly.
He derived that, but to move on to some of the structural properties of this data set, one thing.
It's particularly interesting to look out 'cause it's been studied so much in literature.
Is the degree distribution, specifically the indegree.

Where what we find is that, as expected, we find a very long tailed power law distribution, but you might notice that we're getting a very good fit with the gamma of about a 2.3 here and the sort of accepted value from very large scale web crawls has been about 2.1 in the past, so we've got some disagreement here on what the distribution of in degree of pages is now.
We were sort of measuring two different things.
Of course, because crawlers are measuring a physical, the physical structure of the web, whether or not those links have been used or not.

And of course we're only taking a look at length that user has actually gone on before, so the question is, do we have some sort of sampling bias here and we can at least certainly see that there is some disparity between our indegree measure and the in degree measure you get from a web crawl now.
Which one is correct is very much a philosophical issues.
We were talking about in the last talk of this morning.
If nobody visits a webpage that really exist.

So what we did to just give us an indication that this is a fairly complicated questions we measured are observed in degree of pages versus the in degree that we were able to recover from using the Yahoo API and can see how they compared with each other where the red line here shows a basic exact linear match between what we sample and what Yahoo reports and.
The blue line there is our best fit where we have evidence that, at least in comparison to what a large scale crawl does, we get a systematic sub linear sampling of very popular sites.
But if we take a look at strength and what I mean by strength is of course how many requests are going to each individual web server.
So a basic measure of site traffic.
We find a very, very wide distribution.
We've got pretty close power law fits over almost eight orders of magnitude here.

We've got also an exponent below 2, indicating that for any individual web server, the amount of traffic it gets has unbounded variance and no well defined mean, so we're unable to come to any conclusions about what the average web server out there would seem to expect in terms of traffic.
When we then take a look at the individual weights we see in our network, which would be how heavily traveled the different highways from web server to web server.
Are we again see a very broad distribution over 8 orders of magnitude?
Again fitting a power law with an exponent below 2 indicating that the interconnections between sites also have this extreme heterogeneity and unbounded variance?
So to take a look at some of the behavioral patterns present in the data.
And one of the most.
Things we were interested in studying was finding out taking a look at this referrer field we have in finding out what kind of places people are coming from to get to these pages.

Well, if you take a look at the total proportion of the total strength attributable to different sources, we find out that in the human data set more than half of all the read requests have an empty referrer field in it, indicating perhaps that a user is trying to anonymize their browsing session by.
Withholding it refer information from browsers, but this is this isn't the default case in most web browsers, So what we're actually seeing here is things that people are following.
These links and bookmarks their their browser start page is they're clicked on from instant messages, email, whatever.
These are places that people jump directly to a page without surfing to it.
We also find interesting Lee that the number of web requests that have as a referrer one of the major search engines is a fairly low amount of the total, only about.
Son of all the requests come directly from a search engine, and here I'm just presenting information about traffic.
I invite you to take a look at the paper where we also have some interesting findings regarding a search and how it affects the indegree.
As well.
We do find that the different ratios among these categories are fairly stable overtime in a different context.

If you take a look at the total number of requests overtime that varies quite a bit from month to month, but the proportion of traffic that is attributable to all these different sources up in the upper left there stays a little bit more constant overtime.
We see the same effect when we take a look at time of day, also with along the X axis.

Here we've got midnight to midnight, and though the total volume of traffic we're seeing varies quite a bit over the course of the day, the relative proportion of these different refers is fairly stable overtime.
So once we were armed with this large data set, we were interested in taking a look at the page rank model and seeing to what extent our data set validates the page rank model.
Of the random surfer, so there are a lot of different interpretations of page rank.
What we were interested in focusing in is understanding page rank as the stationary distribution of visit frequency to sites based on an modified random walk with jumps on the web graph.
So Page rank is representing the random server hopping from site to site and.
It's the page rank is going to represent what percentage of the time the random server spends at this site or a basis for comparison.
For that is that we've got this distribution of actual traffic associated with all of these sites.
So what we're interested in is how well does Pagerank predict how much traffic actually lands at these sites now from an application perspective, we're not interested in absolute values of page rank.
Are absolute values of traffic.

We're interested in the differential and ranking between these two algorithms, so we don't really care what what the absolute value of page rank is, but we care whether the same pages are rated high in terms of actual traffic in terms of page rank.
So what we use as a metric for comparing these two measures of rank is Kendall's Tau, which is a way of comparing ranks which of.
Two rank lists are is basically a measure of what percentage of pairs between two rank lists are agreed upon.
If you have a Tau of one that would indicate complete concordance between two rank lists.
If you go all the way down to negative one, that would be complete disagreement and at zero you would have no correlation at all between the list.
So what we do is we take a look at along the X axis.
We have the top end that we're considering from both lists and seeing how much they agree.
So we have our full data set all the way over to the right.
And say at X equal 100, we're comparing the top 100 most highly ranked sites using both traffic and page rank.

So this is the comparison between page rank and actual traffic as we measure from your user data and it's actually not showing a terribly strong correlation here between the two, we get a peek up there tored the end we get into the very low tail where these sites are only getting a few hits, but for the most popular sites we've got very little.
Agreement at all.
Between the two.
Now we're trying to figure out what the reasons for this.
Maybe we can take a look at some of the assumptions that are implicit in the page rank random Surfer model.
First Page Rank assumes that there's an equal probability of teleporting to each one of the nodes.
In other words, when you start some chain of surfing, we assume that any any starting point is equally likely.
Well, of course, intuitively that's not true.

There are some pages that are a lot more popular for somebody to be their browser homepage than than other people aren't going to type in a long URL to start browsing session, they're going to go to Google.
Something like that.
Page Rank also assumes that there's an equal probability of teleporting from each one of the nodes.
In other words, once you get to a node, there's some chance equal for every page that you're going to have somewhere else, well.
Intuitively, that's also not true.
There are some pages that simply aren't as interesting as others, so a browser is going to stop there and go somewhere else.
Page rank is also assuming an equal probability of following each one of the links from any given node.
In other words, once you get to a page, it's assuming that each one of those links is essentially made equal.
Well, if you think a little bit about webpages, that's not true.
There's millions and millions of pages that say best viewed with some particular browser.
I doubt that you're going to follow that link to find out more about this browser, because you already know.
Now this is the third.

Assumption of page rank is very easy to test to see whether we are losing a lot of information by making that assumption, we can come up with a weighted version of page rank in which we are giving a higher weight chance of following any link based on how often we see that link actually followed in practice.
So the hypothesis is maybe we can recover a lot of this information and be able to predict traffic a lot better if we find this weighted Pagerank.
But what we actually find out the.
Blue and red traces there are showing the performance of both page rank and our weighted version of page rank in predicting the actual traffic received by a site.
And as you can see, the weighted version doesn't do a lot better in recovering the traffic, and there is also very high agreement between the weighted and unweighted variants on page rank.
So whatever information is.
Being lossed when you go to page rank instead of taking a look at traffic is not really recovered just by adding those weights.
So we have to take a look at those other assumptions.
So one question that you can raise is local link heterogeneity which.

We took a look before at the distribution of weights on a global scale, but what we're interested in taking a look at here is whether or not, to what extent, is it true that all links on the page are not created equal, so we're taking a look using a measure.
That's all referred to the paper for an intuitive version of what it means, but if we take a look at this graph, we would if we were to find that our data fit.

Just parallel to the X axis there, though it indicates perfect homogenity among the links in a page so that all links are more or less created equal on the page with the Y = X line representing perfect concentration an we certainly find that there is strong local link heterogeneity, implying that of all the links on the page, it's extremely likely that some are going to be followed much more often than others.
We also took a look at the heterogeneity among teleportation targets.
So what we're taking a look at here is on the X axis.
We've got the weights of the links that have the empty referrals and charting the probability density function there.
So this is basically a measure then of.

Sorry, how likely it is that we're going to be teleporting into a page when we find there that not all pages are likely to be start page is indeed we've got a another scale free distribution, 8 orders of magnitude indicating that not only is this uniform across all pages, we've got a very.
Long tail.
When we take a look then at the heterogeneity among US sources, we see basically again heterogeneity, two different source of of sites.
We've got ones over here where we find that the out strength.
In other words the Mount to which this page refers you to other sites and as a source of traffic is much less than the amount of traffic they receive.
So these are places where people stop.
There's a lot of, there's a lot of pages where people get to that page and then don't go any further.
On the other hand, there is this other regime of sites that generate more traffic than they receive, so users actually often go to several places.
From one of these slides, every time they get their innocence.
We can also take a look at some of the sources of popularity for sites.
If we take him, it take a look at.
If we take a look at SN minus, strengthen the empty.
Refer what we have is a measure of how many people got to a particular site by following a link as opposed to just jump in there and then take a look at how that measures up against the distribution.
The distribution of people just jump in there so many plot these against each other.
We find it fairly linear relationship.

Which means that for any particular site, the number of people who get there by jumping immediately there and the number of people who get there from somewhere else are likely to correspond to each other fairly well.
I don't have much time to speak about the temporal patterns that we found, so I will.
Refer to the paper for a more full description of that.

We were interested in taking a look at these temporal patterns briefly because we're interested in coming up with a better algorithms for proxies, cache refreshing, how to do a capacity allocation on web servers, and possibly site design techniques where we're trying to expose a different content based on time of day, perhaps.

So in brief, what we did with that was to come up with a generalized measure of precision and recall for temporal data, where we were going to take a look at a 1 sample of our data that represents an actual sampled subset of the web graph and try and use that sample to predict what actual clicks will be generated by users in the future.
So precision would be a measure of how many future clicks we were able to predict that did wind up happening, and recall would be a measure of how many clicks that actually happened.
Were ones that we thought were going to.
And when we take a look at that data overtime, we see very regular patterns where both precision and recall are following a very strong daily pattern.
That repeats these peaks or day after day for so basically using one hour of data is very easy to predict what's going to happen at the same time one day from now.
And you can see that also tored the right end of the graph where we've got a difference of a week that there's a strong weekly pattern there.
Also Sundays are like Sundays.
Mondays are like Mondays and so on, and you might observe that the troft of the graphs is above a value of .3 indicating there's a strong amount of stationary traffic on the web.
That is exactly the same hour to our day today.
People are visiting the same sites in approximately the same weight to a very large extent.
So to summarize, we've got heterogeneity all over the place in the data set that we observe we've got in both incoming and outgoing site traffic.

The amount of traffic passing over various links, we find that less than half of our traffic actually comes from following links says remember the empty referrer is actually accounting for more than half of all of the human data set.
We find that only about 5% of our traffic is coming directly from search engine, so by and large people arrive at.

A particular page from somewhere else other than a search engine, but this is not including information on chains of clicks which we don't have in our data set, but only 5% is 1 hop away from a search engine.
We've got very high temporal regularity in the data in that it's a fairly predictable overtime.
And we also find that page rank is a poor direct predictor of how much traffic aside is going to get because we have these violations of all of these assumptions of constant distribution.
So we need to take into account all these random teleportation assumptions and random walk assumptions and weigh them with what users actually seem to be doing.
If you want to recover a prediction of trash.

Check where we're going with this in the future is taking a look more into sampling bias and search bias, which is sort of touching on some of the philosophical questions that are mentioned in earlier papers today, in that what really represents something that we're truly measuring and really represents a bias in this.
Do crawlers have a better view of the web then users do?
Well, crawlers recover?
What's their users recover what they're interested in, so it's a philosophical question, were interested from extending our analysis from the host graph too.

Individual pages so that all this information would then repeat using not individual web servers as nodes, but individual web pages and we're interested in improving the random Walker model of the web by taking some of these non uniform distributions and figuring out intelligent ways of.
Adding them to the standard random Walker model to maybe come up with a better predictions for what we can expect to see.
Site graphs.
So thank you very much and I'd like to if we have a few minutes left, any questions you might have.
Thank you, I'm curious about your thoughts on web spam, for example, so it seems like based on your your anonymity function where you strip the IP addresses that you could be vulnerable to web spam.
Specifically someone just generating a bunch of bots that lie about their user agents and just click on pages and potentially not sending refers, which I think just.
Looking at my numbers that I've seen on large traffic sites, you're the pages without refers seems a bit high, so I'm just curious what your thoughts are on web spammers.
OK, so basically our thoughts on web spam is that we feel very fortunate about our user community and that we've got a lot of people with essentially no motivation for spamming.
We've of course we are very vulnerable to spam.
We're implicitly trusting people's user agents, but there's no real commercial interest among the users that.

I you to be spamming or data set, we're not using it for any commercial purpose or really publicizing that we're gathering it, so we're making the implicit assumption that most of our user traffic represents what people were actually doing now.
Wear something like this to be commercialized.
Of course, then you will see all kinds of things show up.
I've certainly seen spam going all the way into fake referrers that are designed that point back to sites that are trying to sell log mining software.
So people will see hits to their sites generated by somebody trying to get through by their software, so we haven't seen that in our data, mostly because we don't.
Our users don't have any implicit motivation to do so now.
Were there any profit mode motive present here?
Absolutely, we would expect to see a lot more spam.
The machine from which an HTTP request originates doesn't need to be the one who has the motivation.
So if a substantial number of machines on the IU campus will be part of a botnet, you lose.
Right, so the point is that of course spam may be generated from systems that I you, whether or not their owners are doing that or not.
And that of course is true we.
Generally have a fairly clean campus, but.
You know, of course there are machines owned and generating all kinds of untoward traffic.
Our hope is that that's a low proportion of the total, and we certainly don't see any very large spikes in traffic overtime.
So basically, if there is a some sort of a botnet or something that was active, it was something that was active over a very long period of time.
It didn't produce a measurable spike in the traffic.
Last question.
So hello, this 5% figure that you give about the traffic from search engines so it does heavily dominated by very big websites like a CNN or Hotmail.
So did you look at the fraction of traffic from search engines to different segments of websites?
Because this is completely completely dominated by the top websites.

Right, so the question is taking a look at the websites were sent to from search engines and this is actually a discussion we have in the paper, so I'd like to direct your attention to that section of the paper.
But to summarize briefly, we found that every time you get a click that's from a search engine that is actually more likely than other clicks to lead you to a web server that you've not seen before.
So the search engine's actually seemed to make it possible to discover a wider variety of websites than you would expect just from random traffic.
In the rest of the data.
Thank you very much again.
